Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: RUI: Multi-Robot Systems for Tracking, Monitoring, and Modeling of Periodic Migratory Populations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Periodic migration patterns can be found throughout the natural world. Examples of periodic movements have been observed in humans, terrestrial and aquatic animals, insects, even bacteria. Understanding such patterns can provide researchers with essential information to making decisions that affect environment, health, finances, and safety. Developing better tools for accurately measuring periodic movements is essential for developing more sophisticated movement models. This project focuses on the development of a mobile, multi-robot sensing system capable of monitoring individuals and populations that share common behaviors resulting in periodic movement patterns. The project uses multiple Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) for monitoring, tracking, and modeling fish populations in their coastal habitat. The specific goals of the project are to (1) develop mathematical models of a population's periodic migratory motion, (2) develop strategies based on these models for real-time estimation of the state of individual's and the population, (3) construct multi-robot control strategies for tracking populations, and (4) conduct continuous monitoring of fish populations using AUVs. To accomplish these goals, a multi-AUV system is deployed to autonomously track and follow acoustic tagged fish populations in Big Fisherman?s Cove in Catalina Island. This test site is a Marine Protected Area abundant with several species of fish that follow periodic migration patterns. Results from experiments are expected to validate the system and generate models that are useful to marine biologists and policy makers.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of this project specific objectives have been met within the field of robotics where advancements have been made in the development of stochastic multi-robot control systems and distributed state estimation for multi-robot target tracking. These advancements have in turn significantly advanced the toolbox for quantifying behavior of marine animals in response to environmental conditions.  Researchers have developed and used Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) to successfully track tagged leopard sharks fitted with “Smart Tags” to accurately determine their geo-position while they follow specific water temperatures.  As well, aerial video of leopard shark aggregations have been processed to develop models and algorithms that can track the movement patterns of a proportion of individuals within an aggregation to accurately predict aggregation size and behavior.  Through this research, a successful integration of methods from computer science, engineering, and marine biology has occurred and lead to interdisciplinary training of students from a variety of disciplines of study.  Most students trained during this project have enrolled in graduate programs in their respective field, or have obtained jobs in industry.  This research has also been presented within outreach programs that have managed to reach 1000s of K-12 students, thereby encouraging careers and opportunities in STEM fields.


Last Modified: 01/30/2018
Modified by: Christopher M Clark
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Over the course of this project specific objectives have been met within the field of robotics where advancements have been made in the development of stochastic multi-robot control systems and distributed state estimation for multi-robot target tracking. These advancements have in turn significantly advanced the toolbox for quantifying behavior of marine animals in response to environmental conditions. Researchers have developed and used Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) to successfully track tagged leopard sharks fitted with "Smart Tags" to accurately determine their geo-position while they follow specific water temperatures. As well, aerial video of leopard shark aggregations have been processed to develop models and algorithms that can track the movement patterns of a proportion of individuals within an aggregation to accurately predict aggregation size and behavior. Through this research, a successful integration of methods from computer science, engineering, and marine biology has occurred and lead to interdisciplinary training of students from a variety of disciplines of study. Most students trained during this project have enrolled in graduate programs in their respective field, or have obtained jobs in industry. This research has also been presented within outreach programs that have managed to reach 1000s of K-12 students, thereby encouraging careers and opportunities in STEM fields.
